posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked:
I have a 8 year old roboRIO that had a very bad day, the CAN Weidmuller and the dual USB A ports are both busted.

One of our mentors has the capabilities to repair it. We were going to do a little hunting on DigiKey to see if we can figure out what the replacement parts are, but I thought I’d ask here to see if anyone knows.

I am not comfortable RMAing this because it was abused, but I hate to recycle it; it still good for running test code.

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: I don’t know about the can and usb-a connectors but incase anyone finds this post, usb-b connector for RIO 2 is this one: https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/te-connectivity-amp-connectors/5788336-1/2188176

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
fovea1959:

the CAN Weidmuller and the dual USB A ports are both busted

You can live without the USB and deploy code and RoboRio imaging over Ethernet. We have a couple like this… CAN on the other hand, unless you use exclusively CTRE stuff through a CANivore or PWM motor control/traditional feedback only, you can’t really get around not having that port.

Edit: see below, I was thinking of the wrong USB port

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
I believe the CAN Weidmuller is this:

https://www.digikey.com/en/products/detail/weidmüller/1825640000/1094380

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked: It’s the dual USB A, not the USB B. We use them for flash drives for a swap file and logging.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
kingc95:

RoboRio imaging over Ethernet

Sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn’t. Couldn’t see any pattern as to the cause and instructions say use USB.

posts.name: fovea1959
posts.cooked: I believe you are correct! Thank you.

posts.name: JBENJI
posts.cooked:
Have you tried contacting NI via the FRC support forum? In previous years, I’ve had real quick turn around with them for replacement RoboRios - 1.0 and 2.0

I know you say its old and abused but might be worth a shot…

https://forums.ni.com/t5/Support/ct-p/Support?profile.language=en

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
I just replaced the CAN connectors with the part that @usbcd36 linked. The Roborio worked properly afterward.

It is easier if the plastic housing of the connector can be removed first by pulling upwards. The contacts for the two positions can then be desoldered and removed one at a time.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: I agree with this procedure, and it’s the one we use at work for board repairs: destroy the part (gently) to give yourself the best chance to save the board.  It helps if the part is already broken, like in this case.  The trouble is when the part isn’t for-sure dead and someone lifts a pad.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: It’s a through-hole part so the risk of lifting pads is much less than for surface mount devices. Someone with experience soldering should not have a problem. I would not recommend having a student do this repair due to the risk of damaging the board.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked:
It’s of more limited use on surface-mount parts – clipping the leads of an attached device isn’t straightforward on many SMD packages.

I agree it’s not a difficult rework job, but I also wouldn’t take the higher risk option, given the cost of the board and the effort involved in trace repair.  The cost of having to remove the shroud for individual desoldering is definitely worth it, IMO.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Did you do anything to remove the conformal coating over the can pins?

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: I don’t recall if there was conformal coating on the pins on the bottom side of the board. It is pretty easy to scratch conformal coating off with an X-Acto knife or a small screwdriver.
